> I do foresee one problem though which became apparent in my multiplexer
> experiments. If we tesselate multiple functions together (and they need
> not be repetitions of the same function) then we now have a far larger
> combination of input values to test against, e.g. in binary input
> problems such as XOR the number of test cases doubles with each extra
> input we add. This of course corresponds to more time per network
> evaluation and so the idea doesn't scale quite as well as might be
> apparent at first.

Yes, this becomes very time-consuming, and is precisely the reason why I 
switched over to learning a controller for a board game instead. The game 
domain allowed even larger input/output spaces (i.e. the kind of problem 
MNEAT could excel at), but performance could be evaluated after letting 
the network play a few games.

> So what we now have is a framework for defining benchmarking problems in
> terms of functional 'circuits' and repetition of those circuits. But now
> I'm thinking that the repetition element is unnecessary, we can just
> hand craft a set of funtional circuits that define a whole range of
> complexity.

Yeah I didn't mean to suggest using repetition as a panacea for generating 
benchmarks; rather, tesselated functions is one area where we can find 
conceptually simple benchmark problems that are surprisingly difficult for 
NEAT. Hence I think they are important because they point out areas in 
which NEAT can be improved.

Anyway, analogous to your circuit idea is using NNs to fit arbitrarily 
complex curves. These can range from easy (composing gaussians) to 
insanely difficult (functions with NK-level ruggedness or other 
nonlinearities). Mattias I think has done some work in this area.

It might help to set up some goals for doing NEAT benchmarking. Is it just 
for the sake of comparability?

Joe
